hints.label: def-swarm-config-space
hints.title: Swarm Configuration Space
hints.content:
62: :label: def-swarm-config-space
63: 
64: The **full swarm configuration space** is:
65: 
66: $$
67: \Sigma_N^{\text{full}} = (\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V} \times \{0,1\})^N
68: 
69: $$
70: 
71: where:
72: - $\mathcal{X} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ is the position state space (Valid Domain)
73: - $\mathcal{V} = \{v \in \mathbb{R}^d : \|v\| \le V_{\text{alg}}\}$ is the velocity ball
74: - $\{0,1\}$ encodes the alive/dead status
75: 
76: The **alive subspace** is:
77: 
78: $$
79: \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}} = \{\mathcal{S} \in \Sigma_N^{\text{full}} : |\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S})| \ge 1\}
80: 
81: $$

hints.label: def-algorithmic-projection-space
hints.title: Algorithmic Projection Space
hints.content:
87: :label: def-algorithmic-projection-space
88: 
89: The **algorithmic space** $\mathcal{Y} \subset \mathbb{R}^m$ is the range of the projection map $\varphi: \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V} \to \mathbb{R}^m$.
90: 
91: For the canonical Adaptive Gas with velocity weighting $\lambda_v > 0$:
92: 
93: $$
94: \varphi(x, v) = (x, \lambda_v v) \in \mathbb{R}^d \times \mathbb{R}^d = \mathbb{R}^{2d}
95: 
96: $$
97: 
98: Thus $m = 2d$ and $\mathcal{Y} = \mathcal{X} \times \lambda_v \mathcal{V}$.
99: 
100: The algorithmic metric is the **Sasaki metric**:
101: 
102: $$
103: d_{\mathcal{Y}}^2(\varphi(x_1, v_1), \varphi(x_2, v_2)) = \|x_1 - x_2\|^2 + \lambda_v^2 \|v_1 - v_2\|^2

hints.label: def-symmetry-transformation
hints.title: Symmetry Transformation
hints.content:
111: :label: def-symmetry-transformation
112: 
113: A **symmetry** of a dynamical system $\mathcal{S}_{t+1} \sim \Psi(\mathcal{S}_t, \cdot)$ is a transformation $T: \Sigma_N \to \Sigma_N$ such that:
114: 
115: $$
116: T(\mathcal{S}_{t+1}) \sim \Psi(T(\mathcal{S}_t), \cdot)
117: 
118: $$
119: 
120: in distribution. That is, applying $T$ before or after the dynamics gives statistically equivalent outcomes.
121: 
122: **Types of symmetries:**
123: 1. **Exact symmetry**: The transition kernel is invariant: $\Psi(T(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot) \circ T^{-1}$
hints.raw_directive:
108: ### 1.2. Symmetry Groups: Definitions
109: 
110: :::{prf:definition} Symmetry Transformation
111: :label: def-symmetry-transformation
112: 
113: A **symmetry** of a dynamical system $\mathcal{S}_{t+1} \sim \Psi(\mathcal{S}_t, \cdot)$ is a transformation $T: \Sigma_N \to \Sigma_N$ such that:
114: 
115: $$
116: T(\mathcal{S}_{t+1}) \sim \Psi(T(\mathcal{S}_t), \cdot)
117: 
118: $$
119: 
120: in distribution. That is, applying $T$ before or after the dynamics gives statistically equivalent outcomes.
121: 
122: **Types of symmetries:**
123: 1. **Exact symmetry**: The transition kernel is invariant: $\Psi(T(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot) \circ T^{-1}$
124: 2. **Statistical symmetry**: The quasi-stationary distribution (QSD) is invariant: $T_* \pi_{\text{QSD}} = \pi_{\text{QSD}}$

hints.label: def-permutation-group
hints.title: Permutation Group
hints.content:
129: :label: def-permutation-group
130: 
131: The **symmetric group** $S_N$ acts on $\Sigma_N$ by permuting walker indices. For $\sigma \in S_N$:
132: 
133: $$
134: \sigma(\mathcal{S}) = ((x_{\sigma(1)}, v_{\sigma(1)}, s_{\sigma(1)}), \ldots, (x_{\sigma(N)}, v_{\sigma(N)}, s_{\sigma(N)}))
135: 
136: $$

hints.label: def-euclidean-group-actions
hints.title: Euclidean Group Actions
hints.content:
142: :label: def-euclidean-group-actions
143: 
144: The **Euclidean group** $E(d) = \mathbb{R}^d \rtimes O(d)$ acts on $\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V}$.
145: 
146: **Translation subgroup** $\mathbb{R}^d$: For $a \in \mathbb{R}^d$,
147: 
148: $$
149: T_a(x, v, s) = (x + a, v, s)
150: 
151: $$
152: 
153: **Rotation subgroup** $SO(d)$: For $R \in SO(d)$,
154: 
155: $$
156: R(x, v, s) = (Rx, Rv, s)
157: 
158: $$

hints.label: def-rho-fitness-potential
hints.title: ρ-Localized Fitness Potential
hints.content:
168: :label: def-rho-fitness-potential
169: 
170: For localization scale $\rho > 0$, the fitness potential at walker $i$ is:
171: 
172: $$
173: V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i, v_i) = \eta^{\alpha + \beta} \exp\left(\alpha Z_\rho[f_k, R, (x_i, v_i)] + \beta Z_\rho[f_k, d, (x_i, v_i)]\right)
174: 
175: $$
176: 
177: where:
178: - $f_k = \frac{1}{k}\sum_{j \in A_k} \delta_{(x_j, v_j)}$ is the empirical measure over alive walkers
179: - $Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z]$ is the localized Z-score:
180: 
181: $$
182: Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z] = \frac{Q(z) - \mu_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}{\sigma'_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}
183: 
184: $$
hints.raw_directive:

179: - $Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z]$ is the localized Z-score:
180:

182: Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z] = \frac{Q(z) - \mu_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}{\sigma'_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}
183:

hints.label: def-emergent-metric
hints.title: Emergent Riemannian Metric
hints.content:
190: :label: def-emergent-metric
191: 
192: The **emergent metric** is the regularized Hessian of the fitness potential:
193: 
194: $$
195: g(x_i, S) = H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I
196: 
197: $$
198: 
199: where:
200: 
201: $$
202: H_i(S) = \nabla^2_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i, v_i)
203: 
204: $$
205: 
206: The **adaptive diffusion tensor** is:
207: 
208: $$
209: D_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) = g(x_i, S)^{-1}
210: 
211: $$
